eil7vmj.Author: tigre1983
eil7vmj.Text:
Two things I think make inflation attractive to world leaders:

Most people don't understand it. They understand taxes, and tax rates or tax increases. They don't understand inflation, thus its a political freebie for governments to pay off debt with inflation. If they had to reduce spending or increases taxes to pay for debt it would be a political nightmare. Inflation is a silent tax. 

Second, $raises$, because people don't have a sure grip on inflation they don't really know if $45k a year is more or less than $40k in 2010. Everyone knows burgers used to be. 25 cents in the 1950s and they now cost dollars, but it's abstract. However, they do know if they get raises or not, and when the last time they got one.  The voting block would riot if wages are flat (not inflation adjusted, just simply flat). Inflation gives people a sense they are moving up, making more, doing well compared to their parents, etc. A world without inflation is a world without raises unless promotion, and a world that makes comparison to the past living standards obvious. Inflation is like a lubricant that keeps everyone churning away without riot. For example:

"I got a raise, my house is worth more than I bought it for and my 401k is up this year and I didn't pay more in taxes to the damn government!"

Even if that person is 'flat' when adjusting for inflation, they are not kicking the current administration out.

eimaj4a.Author: [deleted]
eimaj4a.Text:
The head of Cboe “we will tame the price of bitcoin.” when they realized the price of bitcoin is too expensive to buy for any institution. Cboe started in December 2017 they announce it just 3 weeks before it went live. In that 3 weeks from Nov 30, 2017 to Dec 18, 2017 the price of bitcoin go up from under $10,000 to $20,000.

What do we do? C ask

Let buy as much bitcoin we can and run the price to monumental value, price get to $20,000 

Now let's sell the bitcoin we accumulate. 

Sell the underline as we see it fit and short on future market from $20,000+ down to... and make as much money we can.   
 

Price go from 20000 to 6000  
 

Now the price is low institution like Bakkt, ICE, Bank and all other institution buy every bitcoin they can get from people who must sell to support their life and pay bills, who happen to be the early adopter and the innovator. also due to the price drop some will give up and sell more.   
 

Ok but not enough. where can we get more liquidity?  
 

Let control the narrative.  how?     
 

let's giving out false hope and say we will start ETF soon, when everyone focused on that and forgets the real value of bitcoin, and think ETF is the main reason why bitcoin exist, we just come out and say O no, not now. will do it several times and give different reasons.  
 

we are starting ETF O no we can't, ok now we will next month O no we just pulled out our application ok we applied again.  Get it  
 

Ok now it looks like everyone who is going to sell, sold already   
 

Let's think about this. C ask  
 

If the price go up from this point and we can't sell the underline to control the price it will be bad for us, if someone go long in the future what can we do?  
 

WE WILL NO LONGER OFFER FUTURE.

I’m Just speculating, Maybe the price of bitcoin goes down just because, one of the beast innovation in human history has no use.

eimkzcc.Author: TombStoneFaro
eimkzcc.Text:
I wonder about this also. As I have said before, they are relying on confusion with BTC to succeed; if they were their own crypto, they would avoid this confusion.

They would also be worried about (and I think they are although they don't post about it) falling a notch down on the list of cryptos -- a 10% move in the one of the two cryptos below them will make them lose position and I think in terms of being seen by funds that invest in crypto as something they are allowed to investment in, being in the top 5 or top 10 position is important.

The central idea is, moves in BTC are probably less likely to be the result of manipulation whereas far less money can be used to move the price of bcash. Indeed, I think today's move might be defensive against the two cryptos near it in value -- I doubt if they have a chance to move up to overtake litecoin or eos so they are just worried about slipping.

​

eilkwt9.Author: PhyllisWheatenhousen
eilkwt9.Text: Ledger follows BIP39 for private key generation. This is an open protocol. [On this site](https://iancoleman.io/bip39/) you can enter your passphrase and it will provide your addresses and private keys. It's open source and works offline as well.

eilynub.Author: [deleted]
eilynub.Text: Bitcoin is public key cryptography.  There is no getting anything off of it, but rather obtaining, maintaining, releasing, or transferring control of keys.  Its kind of a weird thing to try to wrap your mind around.  The various devices are just ways of doing those things without having to manually type out keys, or remember keys, or trust keys, or verify keys.    As such, the device vendors have built in safety nets for when the device fails, gets stolen, etc.  But it is not integral to the inherent control of the keys.      hopefully i rambled that coherently

eio57n9.Author: cryptogrip
eio57n9.Text:
Well first of all I like working, long as it's on my own projects. I can't imagine not having a goal or purpose. Not working is not equivalent to financial freedom. 
Secondly, I have been buying bitcoin (and sometimes selling it) for years. But never once did I buy it as a shortcut to financial freedom. I buy it along with real estate, stocks and other investments. I consider it a high risk category because of its nature as an investment based on unchartered territory, but also am well aware of its high likelyhood to eventually be worth many times what it is today. After seeing the obstacles it has already overcome, I am confident that development will continue and easily recognizable advantages of using and owning bitcoin will drive adoption in the years to come. 

Including bitcoin among a diverse investment strategy is wise in my opinion. Depending on it for financial freedom however, is naive.

eilh8u8.Author: mistertilly
eilh8u8.Text:
You argue like a person who has only read and then drawn conclusions from slanted headlines about Jordan Peterson meant to make him look bad.

He has thousands of hours of lectures on Youtube. I've watched hundreds of those hours. Nothing xenophobic about the guy in the slightest—point to an example if I'm wrong, I'd love to see it—don't much care for xenophobes. 

I've been to one of his lectures and read his book 12 Rules for Life. I just don't see the people you're describing or the views you're trying to project onto him and the people who like what he says. 

He deserves critique and there's plenty he says that I have disagree with, but the dude is a centrist if anything, willing to go after identity politics whether it's being played by the Left or the Right. 

P.S. "Please don't idolize Peterson and please don't shoot up innocent people at mosques." could be the most baffling sentence I've ever read. 

It would be like me saying "Please don't idolize Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and please don't rape penguins."

 What does one have to do with the other?

​

ein38q4.Author: idiotsecant
ein38q4.Text: I'm amazed that more people aren't making this point. The TV show Mr Robot, while maybe not the best TV show ever, did paint a pretty accurate picture of where we're headed. Corporate-backed 'stablecoins' are easy to regulate, easy to track, and easy to control. Governments will love them. Real decentralized systems are the opposite of all those things and governments will hate them. It's easy to see which will be viewed more favorably.

ein3swr.Author: tommygunz007
ein3swr.Text: The mob and criminals, under the mask of corporations, will own and run governments. It doesn't matter if banks open or close, coins open or close, They will still have the power. The people will NEVER have the power. It's like the MIT Blackjack kids in vegas. They didn't get barred for _cheating_ they got barred for _winning_. That's my point. If suddenly there is a loss of power due to bitcoin, the laws will change and a smear campaign will go against it, making it the coin of drug lords. Remember, bitcoin has no backing, and no money and therefore no ability to promote itself. There is no government to produce pamphlets or anything else. On the other hand, the US could rename it the 'coin of terror' and suddenly laws would spring up because the mob and criminals can't control it. That's my point in all of this. It doesn't matter what you or the people want, it only matters what those in power want.

ein4ky5.Author: tommygunz007
ein4ky5.Text: that's just it. the reason why it won't go anywhere is because all the people with big money, already know about it. Only ones left is small money, and they don't know enough about markets and investing to even care. It's a pipe dream or fantasy to those small time dollar people. Big money left the game. Small money can't move the value. All that's left is to hope something big will happen globally, and when it does, the first thing people will do is sell sell sell and stockpile fiat in case the power goes out and internet goes out because there will be a run on food and unless you have fiat cash, you starve.

eiliysz.Author: mistertilly
eiliysz.Text:
I asked for you to provide an example that Peterson is xenophobic. Instead you came back with this. Well done. 

"Vile" and "horrible" are also words that can be used to describe morons spouting baseless garbage to slander someone with horrific claims and no proof.

eilk8rq.Author: Nursing_guy
eilk8rq.Text:
The supporters pop up from time to time in waves but their posts get slapped down over time. Permissionless systems attract those who feel marginalized and abused by modern systems, and that includes those that any rational market of ideas should (eventually) punish.

You are attempting to paint Bitcoin with a broad brush, when what you are witnessing is a just a low bar for entry in a social space.
